title: Less Excuses More Solutions (you can worm farm anywhere sis!)

tasks.task: Handle and maintain an Il San hive
subtasks: Approach the Il San hive
Inspect the exterior of the hive
Remove any debris or hanging honeycomb
Check the structural integrity of the hive
Open the hive for interior inspection
Examine the queen bee’s presence and condition
Assess the health of worker bees
Check for signs of parasites or disease
Evaluate the brood health and development
Collect samples of honey or pollen if necessary

tasks.task: Extract honey from the Il San hive
subtasks: Position the hive stand or move the hive
Use a smoker to calm the bees
Apply protective clothing and gear
Remove frames from the hive boxes
Inspect each frame for honeycomb and honey
Use tools to gently pry open frames
Extract honey using extracted honey equipment
Filter the extracted honey
Transfer honey to containers or barrels
Clean tools and equipment used for extraction

tasks.task: Perform swarm control procedures on the Il San hive
subtasks: Monitor the hive for signs of swarming
Identify the queen bee’s whereabouts
Utilize swarm trap or division board for swarm control
Capture the swarm safely
Introduce the captured swarm back into the hive or requeen if necessary

tasks.task: Manage the feeding of the Il San hive
subtasks: Determine the nutritional needs of the bees
Prepare a suitable feed mixture
Measure out and dispense feed into feeding trays
Observe the bees’ consumption and adjust feeding as needed
Clean and maintain feeding equipment

tasks.task: Monitor weather conditions affecting the Il San hive
subtasks: Check forecast for extreme temperatures or weather events
Take measures to protect the hive from cold, heat, rain, etc.
Adjust hive insulation or ventilation as needed

tasks.task: Address predator threats to the Il San hive
subtasks: Survey the area around the hive for potential predators
Install or check predator guards on the hive entrance
Remove any threat signs or active predator activity
